description: From Middle English storie, storye, from Anglo-Norman estorie, from Latin historia, from Ancient Greek ἱστορίᾱ (historíā, “learning through research”), from ἱστορέω (historéō, “to research, inquire (and) record”), from ἵστωρ (hístōr, “the knowing, wise one”), from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (“to see, know”). Doublet of history and storey.

entries.meaning: An account of real or fictional events.

examples: You’ve been telling stories again, haven’t you?

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial, usually pluralized) A soap opera.
examples: What will she do without being able to watch her stories?

entries.meaning: A sequence of events, or a situation, such as might be related in an account.
examples: I tried it again; same story, no error message, nothing happened.
The images it captured help tell a story of extreme loss: 25 percent of its ice and four of its 19 glaciers have disappeared since 1957.

entries.meaning: (social media, sometimes capitalized) A chronological collection of pictures or short videos published by a user on an application or website that is typically only available for a short period.

verbs.description: story (third-person singular simple present stories, present participle storying, simple past and past participle storied)

entries.meaning: To tell as a story; to relate or narrate about.
examples: It is storied of the brazen colossus in Rhodes, that it was seventy cubits high.
Our shop was on the fourth story of the building, so we had to install an elevator.
